Subject: Re: [junit] Don't show exception messages to users (was assertTrue(true))

Kevin Lawrence wrote:

> "Social security number should match the pattern 999-99-9999. AB-1234-XY 
> is not a valid social security number."

You're still thinking like a programmer. "Match the pattern 
999-99-9999". What's that? "Match the pattern" is programmer speak. It's 
a perfectly good exception message for a programmer; but you need to use 
different language when talking to a user. Something like, "AB-1234-XY 
is an invalid social security number. Social security numbers contain 
exactly nine digits, and no letters. Please check the number and try 
again." Furthermore, you might vary the bit about "exactly nine digits, 
and no letters" depending on exactly what they typed. If they typed 
eight digits and no letters, you could say, "Social security numbers 
contain exactly nine digits. 987-6543-2 only has eight."

Programmers are good at writing error messages for other programmers. 
They're not so great at writing error messages for end users. Cedric's 
point about using technical writers to write understandable exception 
messages in J2EE systems is well taken. However, to the extent that's 
necessary it's a failure in the design of J2EE. J2EE does not properly 
separate the two different tasks of providing information to the 
system's programmers and to the system's administrators. In practice, 
system administrators are probably more comfortable with 
programmer-speak than a typical end user is, so the line is starting to 
blur a bit. However, it's still the case that an administrator is not a 
developer. What you put in an error log for an administrator to inspect 
is not necessarily the same thing you want to show to a developer. A 
well-designed system (and I'm not saying J2EE is such a system) does not 
require using the same messages for different classes of people.
